Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effects of Emissions Trading

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project directly tests if and to what extent emissions trading results in the reduction it is designed to achieve. Specifically, this will help determine if emissions trading is associated with such reduction at both the city-level and at the firm-level on a global scale. The results will contribute relevant insight for addressing time-sensitive matters for formulation and implementation at national, state, and city levels. This includes but is not limited to the efficacy of emissions trading participation and whether alternative options such as a tax are more viable than a market approach. Results will contribute to greater efficacy in emissions reduction, which in turn is likely to yield long-term public health and national security dividends.

This project uses original data on city-level emissions change for 269 cities from between 2000 and 2013 to be treated as a dependent variable in linear regression modeling. Controlling for many socio-economic and situational factors, two independent variables of interest will be tested for association with urban emissions change, derived from two sources: (1) a database comprising full firm-level transaction data for eight national emissions trading systems, and (2) a corporate emissions database, which comprises the emissions from 403 of the largest 500 companies in the world by market capitalization. First, emissions trading transactions will be collated from the firm-level to the city-level and tested for association with city-level emissions reduction. Second, corporate emissions change will be (a) tested as an independent variable against city-level emissions change to determine if corporate change influences the emissions change of the cities in which they reside; and then (b) tested as a dependent variable against emissions trading system participation as an independent variable, to determine whether participation in emissions trading influences corporate emissions reduction. Last, a qualitative analysis of cases both within and outside emissions trading systems will be performed, assessing on-the-ground processes associated with success and failure of emissions reduction by cities and firms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the project are to test if and to what extent city-level and firm (corporate)-level participation in emissions trading systems, or ETS, also known as the "carbon market" is associated with the greenhouse gas emissions reductions it is designed to achieve. This test is performed in three portions. First, I test the relationship between corporate greenhouse gas emissions reduction versus emissions trading activity using the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) corporate climate change performance database (N=~2,800). Second, I test the relationship between emissions change in 331 cities across 49 countries and collective city-level emissions trading activity. Third, I test the relationship between emissions change in the same cities and the emissions change of CDP-disclosing corporations housed within those cities. Fig. 1 displays all ETS transactions, Fig. 2 displays all corporate facility emissions change and Fig. 3 displays all urban emissions change.

I find that (1) neither carbon credit purchases nor ETS participation are significantly associated with firm-level emissions change, but that the act of firms setting emissions reduction targets is associated with emissions reduction (see Table 1). (2) Collective city-level activity of ETS-participating firms is unassociated with urban emissions change (see Table 2). (3) Facility-level emissions change is unassociated with the collective urban emissions change of the cities in which the firms are located (see Table 3.)

Cities with more CDP-disclosing firms are more likely to reduce collective urban emissions than those with less. Further testing shows that in addition to the stringency of national climate change regulation, two city-level factors have a stronger association to emissions reduction than the presence of CDP-disclosing firms: The number of environmental management consultancies and city government memberships in environmentally-oriented transnational municipal networks. These mechanisms of urban emissions reduction and the processes they carry out are relevant to global efforts to achieve a "green recovery" from the COVID-19 pandemic-induced recession.  

These findings evince that ETS is not sufficient for reducing greenhouse gas emissions at the firm- or city-level. This supports broader research arguing that market-based climate change governance mechanisms do not affect physical emissions reduction, and are thus no substitute for traditional governance.
